data.title: Avast Vs. AVG (2024 Comparison)
data.meta_description: Antivirus software is a must-have cybersecurity solution for protection against viruses, malware & ransomware. Read this comparison between Avast vs. AVG.
data.text:
Antivirus software is a must-have cybersecurity solution for protecting your device against viruses, malware and ransomware. However, not all antivirus solutions are the same, and some are better at detecting malicious activity than others. In this article, we’re going to compare two of the top providers on the market: Avast vs. AVG.

Why We Picked It

Avast provides small companies with a versatile antivirus and endpoint protection tool, which can not only detect malware in real time but adds additional capabilities including password protection and data shredding to protect against threats.

The solution is thus a good choice for small teams that want to keep Windows, Mac, Android and iOS devices from the latest threats and vulnerabilities.

Why We Picked It

AVG is a solid antivirus solution that has a proven ability to detect the latest viruses and malware as part of independent testing. It also has a range of features that are ideal for business users, including SharePoint protection, which can analyze files downloaded or uploaded via a user’s servers.

The solution also provides password protection so that users can block certain apps from accessing passwords stored in their web browser. It’s worth noting that it offers 24/7 customer support via call centers in the U.S., U.K. and Australia.

Avast vs. AVG: At a Glance

Avast is a complete and affordable antivirus solution that offers a range of capabilities including password protection, data shredding, webcam protection, sandboxing and more.

Anti-Virus Guard, or AVG, is another top antivirus solution produced by the same parent company as Avast, which can be used to scan for malware and other threats. AVG comes with two-way password protection, a firewall, VPN encryption and data shredding.

At a high level, both Avast and AVG provide small companies with viable solutions to protect their endpoints from the viruses and malware that actors use to target modern businesses.

How Avast vs. AVG Stack Up

Each of these antivirus solutions is highly reliable and easy to deploy, and very competitive in a number of key areas.

Scan Accuracy

Both Avast and AVG are highly accurate antivirus solutions with identical scores. For instance, both Avast and AVG offer a 94.2% off-line detection rate, a 99.5% online detection rate and a 99.98% online protection rate.

These rates are competitive with or outperform some of the detection rates offered by third-party vendors including Bitdefender, Malwarebytes and McAfee.

Password Protection

Both Avast and AVG provide organizations with their password protection capabilities. For example, Avast’s password protection capabilities enable users to select which apps can access passwords stored in the web browser.

AVG’s password protection not only allows users to determine whether an app can access their passwords or not, but also notifies the user if a password entered in the browser is weak, duplicated or has been leaked online. This provides a valuable heads-up if they’re using passwords that are easy to crack.

Sandboxing

One key area where Avast differentiates itself from AVG is in its inclusion of sandboxing capabilities. With Avast’s Sandbox, users can run applications in a safe environment that’s isolated from the rest of their PC.

In effect, this means that the user can download and run distrustful applications, or access unknown files while minimizing the risk of compromising their device. AVG doesn’t offer any sandboxing capabilities at this time.

Cost of Avast vs. AVG

Paid plans for Avast range from INR 4,144.79 ($49.99) to INR 6,632.17 ($79.99) per year for a range of products including Avast One, Avast Premium Security, Avast Home Office Solutions, Avast Small Business Cybersecurity Solutions and the Advanced Protection Plan. Pricing for each product is summarized briefly below:

Avast One: All-in-one malware and virus protection with an unlimited VPN and data breach monitoring. Pricing starts at INR 4,168.84 ($50.28) per year.

Avast Premium Security: An antivirus protection package that helps defend against phishing websites. Costs INR 4,144.79 ($49.99) for the first year for up to 10 devices.

Avast Small Office Protection: Antivirus platform with 24/7 technical support. Costs INR 11.606.91 ($139.99) per year plus $14 per device per year.

Avast Essential Business Security: An online management platform offering identity protection, patch management, VPNs and identity management. Prices start at INR 12,300.89 ($148.36) per year plus INR 2,460.01 ($29.67) per device per year.

Prices for AVG range from INR 4,964.80 ($59.88) to INR 6,632.17 ($79.99) per year. Pricing for each product is summarized briefly below:

AVG Internet Security: Antivirus and malware with ransomware protection and anti-phishing website protection. Costs INR 4,964.80 ($59.88) per year and supports up to 10 devices.

AVG Ultimate: Blocks viruses, malware and ransomware with additional storage space and a secure VPN. Costs INR 6,632.17 ($79.99) per year and supports up to 10 devices.

Customer Reviews & Reputation

Data Shredding

Both Avast and AVG provide users with data shredding capabilities. Avast’s Data Shredder can be used to permanently delete files so that they can’t be retrieved. This means that if someone steals the device, they won’t be able to recover any destroyed content.

AVG also offers data shredding so you can delete files and folders. You can also delete entire drives if you have multiple partitioned drives on your PC.

Encryption

Both Avast and AVG offer virtual private networks (VPNs) that protect the user’s sessions with “military grade” AES-256 bit encryption. This means that the user’s internet service provider (ISP) will be unable to track what sites they visit.

It also means that they can connect to public Wi-Fi without worrying about anyone eavesdropping on their browsing activity. Avast and AVG each support up to 10 devices at once with a reasonable download speed.

Firewall

Each of the two providers also offers a firewall feature to manage traffic between the user’s device and the public internet. Avast’s firewall controls when an app can connect to the internet or a private network, and gives the users prompts so they can manually allow or deny connection attempts.

There are also firewall logs where the user can view a summary of blocked apps, devices and applied rules. There’s also a premium upgrade which provides additional capabilities such as leak protection, port scan alerts and ARP spoofing alerts.

Similarly, AVG allows the user-to-monitor incoming and outgoing traffic from their device to the internet, giving the user the option to choose from custom or default rules for each app. Along with Avast, users can also configure firewall prompts to manually allow or block each connection. Likewise, firewall logs allow users to view a summary of blocked apps, devices and applied rules.

Wi-Fi Scanning

Another feature that stands out with Avast is its Wi-Fi scanning feature. Avast can scan a user’s Wi-Fi network to identify vulnerabilities in the network that could be compromised to gain access to their private data. Likewise, with Avast Premium Security, users can receive an alert whenever someone joins the network.

Wi-Fi scanning is a useful addition because it helps to increase the user’s transparency over their network activity so they can be notified about other threats to their data. AVG doesn’t offer a similar service at this time.

Top Avast and AVG Alternatives

While Avast and AVG are high-performance antivirus tools, there are a number of competitive providers such as Bitdefender and Norton Antivirus that also offer extremely reliable experiences. Some of these top alternatives are listed below:

Bottom Line

Avast and AVG are both extremely competitive across the board with high malware detection rates, but Avast has the edge due to its comprehensive base feature set and its inclusion of sandboxing.

Having a sandboxing capability really decreases the chance of a device being compromised because it adds an extra layer of protection in the event that an employee makes the mistake of downloading a malicious file. Its customer support is also solid.
